<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg11901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> C. SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND BASIS OF PRESENTATION (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company commissioned a study to determine whether Sections&nbsp;382 or 383 could limit the use of our carryforwards in this manner. After completing this study, the company has
concluded that the limitation will not have a material impact on its ability to utilize its net operating loss or credit carryforwards. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
tax years 1996 through 2010 remain open to examination by major taxing jurisdictions to which the Company is subject, which are primarily in the United States, as carryforward
attributes generated in years past may still be adjusted upon examination by the Internal Revenue Service or state tax authorities if they are or will be used in a future period. The Company is
currently not under examination by the Internal Revenue Service or any other jurisdiction for any tax years. The Company did not recognize any interest and penalties associated with unrecognized tax
benefits in the accompanying financial statements. The Company would record any such interest and penalties as a component of interest expense. The Company does not expect any material changes to the
unrecognized benefits within 12&nbsp;months of the reporting date. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Accounting for Stock-based Compensation  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has several stock-based employee compensation plans, as well as stock options issued outside of such plans as an inducement
to engage new executives. Stock-based compensation cost is measured at the grant date based on the value of the award and is recognized as expense over the service period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company uses the Black-Scholes valuation model for valuing options. This model incorporates several assumptions, including volatility, expected life and discount rate. The Company
uses historical volatility as it believes it is more reflective of market conditions and a better indicator of volatility. The Company uses historical information in the calculation of expected life
for its "plain-vanilla" option grants. If the Company determines that another method used to estimate expected volatility is more reasonable than the Company's current methods, or if another method
for calculating these input assumptions is prescribed by authoritative guidance, the fair value calculated for share-based awards could change significantly. Higher volatility and longer expected
lives would result in an increase to share-based compensation determined at the date of grant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company recognized the full impact of its share-based payment plans in the consolidated financial statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 and did not
capitalize any such costs on the consolidated balance sheets, as such costs that qualified for capitalization were not </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
 </DIV>
 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation
expense associated with the granting of stock options to employees is being recognized on a straight line basis over the service period of the option. In instances where the
actual compensation expense would be greater than that calculated using the straight line method, the actual compensation expense is recorded in that period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Included
in the 2010 stock-based compensation expense above are amounts related to employees participation in the Employee Stock Purchase Plan ("ESPP") of approximately $221,000. See
Note&nbsp;L, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Employee Benefit Plan</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2010, approximately $11.0&nbsp;million in unrecognized compensation expense remains to be recognized in future periods. The table below summaries the recognition
of the deferred compensation expense associated with employee stock options over the next four years as follows: </FONT></P>

 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company accelerated unvested options for two of its senior executives in connection with their departures. In addition, the Company
extended the time to exercise these options, normally ninety days, to two years from the date of their respective last days of employment. As a result, the Company recorded a non-cash
restructuring charge in 2008 of </FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>approximately
$0.3&nbsp;million, of which approximately $0.1&nbsp;million related to the acceleration of unvested options and $0.2&nbsp;million related to the extension of time to exercise these
options. The Company valued these changes using the Black-Scholes option pricing model. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
weighted-average grant-date fair value of options granted during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 were $1.92, $1.50 and $2.03, respectively, per
option. The fair value of each stock option is estimated on the date of the grant using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model with the following range of assumptions: </FONT></P>

 <!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
option life was determined using actual option experience. Prior to March&nbsp;31, 2010, the option life was determined using the simplified method
for estimating expected option life, which qualify as "plain-vanilla" options.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
stock volatility for each grant is measured using the weighted average of historical daily price changes of the Company's common stock over the most
recent period equal to the expected option life of the grant, the historical short term trend of the option and other factors, such as expected changes in volatility arising from planned changes in
the Company's business operations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
risk-free interest rate for each grant is equal to the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant for instruments with a
similar expected life.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
estimated forfeiture rate for each option grant is between 0% and 6.25%. The Company periodically reviews the estimated forfeiture rate, in light of
actual experience. </FONT></DD></DL>
 </DIV>
 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Net Loss per Basic and Diluted Common Share  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reports net loss per basic and diluted common share in accordance with standards established for computing and presenting
earnings per share. Basic earnings per share excludes dilution and is computed by dividing income attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for
the period. Diluted earnings per share reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock were exercised or converted into common stock or resulted
in the issuance of common stock that then shared in the earnings of the Company, except when the effect would be anti-dilutive. See Note&nbsp;R, Loss Per Share, for more information
related to options, warrants and convertible Preferred Stock which would be considered anti-dilutive. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>54</FONT></P>

<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> C. SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND BASIS OF PRESENTATION (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Concentration of Credit Risk  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial instruments that subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk principally consist of cash equivalents, trade accounts
receivable, unbilled contract costs and deposits in bank accounts. The Company deposits its cash and invests in short-term investments primarily through a national commercial bank.
Deposits in excess of amounts insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) are exposed to loss in the event of nonperformance by the institution. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's trade accounts receivable and unbilled contract costs and fees are primarily from sales to commercial customers. The Company does not require collateral and has not
historically experienced significant credit losses related to receivables, letters of credit or unbilled contract costs and fees from individual customers or groups of customers in any particular
industry or geographic area. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant
customers are defined as those customers that account for 10% or more of total net revenue in a fiscal year or 10% or more of accounts receivable and unbilled contract costs
and fees at the end of a fiscal period. The table below details out customers that were considered significant, greater than 10%, as it pertains to both annual revenues for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 and accounts receivable and unbilled contract costs as of December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009. </FONT></P>
 <DIV style="padding:0pt;position:relative;width:54%;margin-left:10%;">
<p style="font-family:times;"><font size=1></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLEWIDTH,"150%" -->


 </FONT></P>

<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;"><BR><FONT SIZE=2>Fuel Cell Energy,&nbsp;Inc.(approximately 17%)</FONT></TD>

 <!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>*</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Represents
less than 10% of either the fiscal year revenue or the total accounts receivable balance at December&nbsp;31, 2009 or 2008.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>**</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
accounts receivable associated with these customers were backed by irrevocable letters of credit at December&nbsp;31, 2010. </FONT></DD></DL>
 </DIV>
 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Research and Development Costs  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company expenses research and development costs as incurred. Cost of research and development and other revenue includes costs
incurred in connection with both funded research and development and other revenue arrangements and unfunded research and development activities. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Comprehensive Income (Loss)  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Comprehensive income (loss) includes net loss and foreign currency translation adjustments prior to the changing of the functional
currency in Canada to the US dollar. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>55</FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> C. SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND BASIS OF PRESENTATION (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Fair Value of Financial Instruments  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's financial instruments consist of cash equivalents, accounts receivable, unbilled contract costs and fees, warrants to
purchase shares of common stock, accounts payable, subordinated note payable and the line of credit. The estimated fair values of these financial instruments approximate their carrying values at
December&nbsp;31, 2010 and December&nbsp;31, 2009. The estimated fair values have been determined through information obtained from market sources and management estimates. The Company's warrant
liability is recorded at fair value. See "Fair Value Measurements" below. The carrying value of the subordinated notes payable, as of December&nbsp;31, 2010, is not materially different from the
fair value of the notes. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Fair Value Measurements  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's financial assets and liabilities are measured using inputs from the three levels of fair value hierarchy which are as
follows: </FONT></P>
 <DIV style="padding:0pt;position:relative;width:100%;margin-left:0%;">
<p style="font-family:times;"><font size=1></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLEWIDTH,"100%" -->


 </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE width="100%"  BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR><!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS SET -->
<TD WIDTH="45pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="17pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS END --></TR>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Level&nbsp;1</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2> &#151;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2> Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Level&nbsp;2</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2> &#151;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2> Inputs other than Level&nbsp;1 that are observable, either directly or indirectly, such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are not active; or other inputs that are
observable or can be corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the assets or liabilities.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Level&nbsp;3</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2> &#151;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2> Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<DIV style="padding:0pt;position:relative;text-align:left;margin-left:10%;">
 <!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's Level&nbsp;2 financial liabilities consist of long term investor warrant liabilities comprised of the Warrant&nbsp;As, Warrant&nbsp;Cs,
the warrants issued to the investors in connection with the 2007 preferred stock financing (the "2007 Financing Warrants") and the placement agent warrants. The fair value of the Warrant&nbsp;As and
Warrant&nbsp;Cs is being estimated using a binomial lattice model for the portion not included in the outstanding call option at December&nbsp;31, 2010 and for approximately 50% of the outstanding
Warrant&nbsp;As and Warrant&nbsp;Cs subject to the call the valued using their intrinsic value and the fair value of the placement agent warrants and the 2007 Financing Warrants is being estimated
using the Black-Scholes option pricing model. (see Note&nbsp;G. Warrant&nbsp;Liabilities; Note&nbsp;I&#151;Redeemable Convertible Series&nbsp;B and Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock; and
"Warrant&nbsp;Liabilities" below).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Included
as a component of cash and cash equivalents on accompanying consolidated balance sheets. </FONT></DD></DL>
 </DIV>
 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Warrant&nbsp;Liabilities  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;1, 2009, the Company adopted ASC 815-40-15 to evaluate whether an instrument is considered
indexed to an entity's own stock. The Company's evaluation of the 2007 Financing Warrants determined that the 2007 Financing Warrants covering 19,799,023 shares of common stock did not qualify for a
scope exception under ASC 815-40-15 as they were determined not to be indexed to the Company's stock as prescribed by ASC 815-40-15. As a result, on the
date of adoption, January&nbsp;1, 2009, the Company reclassified these warrants from additional paid in capital to warrant liabilities through a cumulative effect of a change in accounting
principle. The initial value of the warrant liability at adoption was $22,041,541. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the period through July&nbsp;3, 2009, the Company recorded a charge to change in fair value of warrants of approximately $3.2&nbsp;million for the increase in the fair value
related to these warrants during the period. The warrants did not qualify for hedge accounting, and as such, all subsequent changes in the fair value of these warrants were recognized currently in
earnings until such time as the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>57</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_ft11901_1_58"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg11901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> C. SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND BASIS OF PRESENTATION (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>warrants
were modified in the manner described below, or exercised or expired. These common stock purchase warrants do not trade in an active securities market, and as such, the Company estimated the
fair value of these warrants using the Black-Scholes option pricing model using the following assumptions: </FONT></P>
 <DIV style="padding:0pt;position:relative;width:60%;margin-left:20%;">
<p style="font-family:times;"><font size=1></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLEWIDTH,"100%" -->


 </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE width="100%"  BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR><!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS SET -->
<TD WIDTH="" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="86pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="86pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="86pt" style="font-family:times;"></TD>
<!-- TABLE COLUMN WIDTHS END --></TR>

<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>January&nbsp;1, 2009 </B></FONT></TH>
<TH style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:solid #000000 1.0pt;"><FONT SIZE=1><B>April&nbsp;4, 2009 </B></FONT></TH>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
 </DIV>
 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;3, 2009, the Company modified certain provisions contained within the 2007 Financing Warrants. Under the terms of the original 2007 Financing Warrants (prior to their
modification), in addition to standard anti-dilution protection for stock splits or dividends, stock combinations, mergers, liquidation or similar events, the exercise price and number of
shares issuable upon exercise of these warrants were subject to adjustment in the event of certain dilutive issuances (the "Dilutive Issuance Provision"). Upon each adjustment of the exercise price
pursuant to the Dilutive Issuance Provision, the number of shares subject to the warrant were also to be adjusted by multiplying the current exercise price prior to the adjustment by the number of
shares subject to the warrant and dividing the product by the exercise price resulting from the adjustment. The Dilutive Issuance Provision was modified to (i)&nbsp;limit the instances in which a
dilutive issuance will cause an adjustment to the exercise price of the warrants and (ii)&nbsp;eliminate the provision that correspondingly increased the number of shares underlying the warrants in
the event of a dilutive issuance that causes an adjustment to the exercise price. As a result of this modification these warrants were determined to be equity instruments by the Company, as they now
qualify for the scope exception under ASC 815-40-15. Previously the warrants, due to the adoption of the provisions
of ASC 815-40, were accounted for as a derivative liability. The Company is no longer required to mark these warrants to fair value each quarter. See Note&nbsp;G.
Warrant&nbsp;Liabilities. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the Company determined the fair value of the investor warrants (the Warrant&nbsp;As and Warrant&nbsp;Cs) and placement agent warrants using valuation models it considers
to be appropriate. The Company's stock price has the most significant influence on the fair value of its warrants. An increase in the Company's common stock price would cause the fair values of the
warrants to increase, because the exercise price of the warrants is fixed at $1.815 per share, and result in a charge to our statement of operations. A decrease in the Company's stock price would
likewise cause the fair value of the warrants to decrease and result in a credit to our statement of operations. See Note&nbsp;G. for valuation discussion. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Redeemable Convertible Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company initially accounted for its issuance of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and associated warrants by allocating the proceeds
received net of transaction costs based on the relative fair value of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and the warrants issued to the investors, and then to any beneficial conversion rights
contained in the convertible redeemable preferred securities. The Company </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>58</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_ft11901_1_59"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg11901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> C. SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND BASIS OF PRESENTATION (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>determined
the initial value of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and investor warrants using valuation models it considers to be appropriate. The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock was classified
within the liability section of the Company's balance sheet. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
October 2010, the holders of the remaining 75 shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock converted their shares into common stock, resulting in the issuance of 251,677 shares of common
stock. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Redeemable Convertible Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company initially accounted for its issuance of Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock and associated warrants by allocating the proceeds
received net of transaction costs based on the relative fair value of the Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock and the warrants issued to the investors, and then to any beneficial conversion rights
contained in the convertible redeemable preferred securities. The Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock is classified as temporary equity on the balance sheet. The Company
determined the initial value of the Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock and investor warrants using valuation models it considers to be appropriate. The Company used the effective interest method to
accrete the carrying value of the Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock through the earliest possible redemption date (November&nbsp;8, 2011), at which time the value of the Series&nbsp;C Preferred
Stock would have been $30.0&nbsp;million or 120% of its face value and dividends. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
October&nbsp;27, 2010, the holders of all of the outstanding shares of Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock converted their shares and accumulated dividends into common stock, resulting
in the issuance of 27,526,344 shares of common stock. To induce the Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock holders to convert their shares, the Company paid these holders an aggregate $1.25&nbsp;million in
cash upon conversion. The entitlement to a redemption of the Series&nbsp;C Preferred Shares was eliminated upon the holders' conversion of the Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock into common shares in
October 2010. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> D. DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2010, the Company sold its Applied Technology business unit for approximately $1.0&nbsp;million in cash and $0.5&nbsp;million in working capital retained at the date of
the sale. Prior to the sale the Applied Technology business unit was reported by the Company as its own operating segment. Operations associated with the Applied Technology business unit have been
reclassified as income (loss) from discontinued operations in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations, and cash flows associated with this segment are included in cash flows from
discontinued operations in the consolidated statements of cash flows. The Company evaluated the assets of the Applied Technology business unit and as of December&nbsp;31, 2009 had classified them as
held for sale. The Company recorded a gain on the sale of the Applied Technology business unit of approximately $0.5&nbsp;million in its results of operations for the first quarter of 2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
September&nbsp;26, 2008, the Company sold its Electronics and Power Systems US business segments to two unrelated companies, for approximately $5.6&nbsp;million in cash and
$0.5&nbsp;million of retained accounts receivable. The Company recorded a gain on the sale of the Electronics and Power Systems US business segments of approximately $0.3&nbsp;million in 2008.
Prior to the sale, each of these divisions were reported by the Company as its own operating segment. Operations associated with these discontinued segments have been classified as loss from
discontinued operations in the accompanying </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>59</FONT></P>

<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;border-bottom:double #000000 2.25pt;">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
 </DIV>
 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
provision for excess and obsolete inventory, from continuing operations, net of usage, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $1,089,950, $185,577 and
$360,035, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> G. WARRANT LIABILITIES  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Warrants Issued in Connection with the July 2006 Financing  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the July&nbsp;19, 2006 private placement of $12.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of senior secured
convertible notes (which notes were subsequently retired by cash redemption in November 2007), the Company issued: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Warrant&nbsp;As  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Warrant&nbsp;As originally entitled the holders thereof to purchase up to an aggregate of 3,636,368 shares of the Company's
common stock at a price of $1.815 per share for a period beginning six months from the date of such warrants and ending on the seventh anniversary of the date of such warrants. The period prior to six
months from the date of the warrants is hereinafter referred to as the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>61</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=61,EFW="2202706",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=233717,FOLIO='61',FILE='DISK106:[11ZAE1.11ZAE11901]FT11901A.;7',USER='JJORGE',CD='14-MAR-2011;23:13' -->
<A NAME="page_ft11901_1_62"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg11901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> G. WARRANT LIABILITIES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>"non-exercise
period." The exercise price and the number of shares underlying these warrants are subject to adjustment for stock splits, stock dividends, combinations, distributions of
assets or evidence of indebtedness, mergers, consolidations, sales of all or substantially all assets, tender offers, exchange offers, reclassifications or compulsory share exchanges. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If
a change of control of the Company occurs, as defined, the holders may elect to require the Company to purchase the Warrant&nbsp;As for a purchase price equal to the Black-Scholes
value of the remaining unexercised portion of each Warrant&nbsp;A. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
so long as any Warrant&nbsp;As remain outstanding, the Company may not issue any common stock or common stock equivalents at a price per share less than $1.65. In the event of a
breach of this provision, the holders may elect to require the Company to purchase the Warrant&nbsp;As for a purchase price equal to the Black-Scholes value of the remaining unexercised portion of
each Warrant&nbsp;A. As a result of the November&nbsp;8, 2007 and December&nbsp;20, 2007 preferred stock financing, as described in Note&nbsp;I below, the holders were entitled for a limited
period of time (45&nbsp;days after each issuance) to exercise this right. During fiscal 2007, the Company paid approximately $1.4&nbsp;million to redeem Warrant&nbsp;As representing 1,242,426
shares of common stock. During 2008, the Company paid approximately $0.4&nbsp;million to redeem Warrant&nbsp;As representing 303,031 shares of common stock. (See table below for assumptions used
in valuing the warrants redeemed). During 2010 warrants to purchase 954,547 shares of common stock were exercised. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010, Warrant&nbsp;As to purchase 1,136,364 shares of
common stock were outstanding. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If
the closing bid price per share of our common stock for any 20 consecutive trading days exceeds 200% of the exercise price, then, if certain conditions are satisfied, including
certain equity conditions, the Company may require the holders of the Warrant&nbsp;As to exercise up to 50% of the unexercised portions of such warrants. If the closing bid price per share of our
common stock for any 20 consecutive trading days exceeds 300% of the exercise price, then, if certain equity conditions are satisfied, the Company may require the holders of the Warrant&nbsp;As to
exercise all or any part of the unexercised portions of such warrants. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Warrant&nbsp;Bs  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Warrant&nbsp;Bs entitled the holders thereof to purchase up to an aggregate of 3,636,368 shares of the Company's common stock at
a price of $1.68 per share for a period of 90 trading days beginning the later of six months from the date of such warrants and the date the SEC declares effective the Registration Statement. As a
result of an amendment, the expiration date of the Warrant&nbsp;Bs was extended to August&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;17, 2007, the holders of the Warrant&nbsp;Bs exercised such warrants in full, acquiring 3,636,638 shares of common stock at $1.31 per share. The Company received
proceeds of approximately $4.8&nbsp;million. To entice the holders of the Warrant&nbsp;Bs to exercise such warrants the Company reduced the exercise price from $1.68 to $1.31 per share. As a
result of reducing the exercise price the Company recorded a charge to operations in 2007 related to the warrant modification of approximately $0.9&nbsp;million to change in fair value of the
Convertible Notes and warrants on the accompanying statement of operations. Pursuant to the original terms of the Warrant&nbsp;Bs, upon exercise of the Warrant&nbsp;Bs, the warrant holders were
entitled to receive additional warrants ("Warrant&nbsp;Cs") to </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>62</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> G. WARRANT LIABILITIES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>purchase
a number of shares of common stock equal to 50% of the number of shares of common stock purchased upon exercise of the Warrant&nbsp;Bs. As a result of the full exercise of the
Warrant&nbsp;Bs, the holders received Warrant&nbsp;Cs to purchase 1,818,187 shares of common stock at an exercise price of $1.815 per share for a period beginning six months from the date of such
warrants and ending on the seventh anniversary of the date of such warrants. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Warrant&nbsp;Cs  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed above, upon the exercise of the Warrant&nbsp;Bs, the holders were entitled to receive additional warrants (the
"Warrant&nbsp;Cs"). The Warrant&nbsp;Cs originally entitled the holders thereof to purchase up to an aggregate of 1,818,187 shares of our common stock at a price of $1.815 per share for a period
beginning six months from the date of such warrants and ending on the seventh anniversary of the date of such warrants. The period prior to six months from the date of the warrants is hereinafter
referred to as the "non-exercise period." The exercise price and the number of shares underlying these warrants are subject to adjustment for stock splits, stock dividends, combinations,
distributions of assets or evidence of indebtedness, mergers, consolidations, sales of all or substantially all assets, tender offers, exchange offers, reclassifications or compulsory share exchanges. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If
a change of control of the Company occurs, as defined, the holders may elect to require the Company to purchase the Warrant&nbsp;Cs for a purchase price equal to the Black-Scholes
value of the remaining unexercised portion of each Warrant&nbsp;C. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
so long as any Warrant&nbsp;Cs remain outstanding, the Company may not issue any common stock or common stock equivalents at a price per share less $1.65. In the event of a breach
of this provision, the holders may elect to require the Company to purchase the Warrant&nbsp;Cs for a purchase price equal to the Black-Scholes value of the remaining unexercised portion of each
Warrant&nbsp;C. As a result of the November&nbsp;8, 2007 and December&nbsp;20, 2007 preferred stock financing, as described in Note&nbsp;I below, the holders were entitled for a limited period
of time (45&nbsp;days after each issuance) to exercise this right. During 2007, the Company paid approximately $0.7&nbsp;million to redeem Warrant&nbsp;Cs representing 621,215 shares of common
stock. During 2008, the Company paid approximately $0.2&nbsp;million to redeem Warrant&nbsp;Cs representing 151,516 shares of common stock. (See table below for assumptions used in valuing the
warrants redeemed). During 2010 warrants to purchase 431,819 shares of common stock were exercised. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010, Warrant&nbsp;Cs to purchase 613,637 shares of common stock were
outstanding. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If
following the later of (i)&nbsp;the effective date of the Registration Statement and (ii)&nbsp;the six month anniversary of the issuance date, the volume weighted average price
per share of the Company's common stock for any 20 consecutive trading days exceeds 200% of the exercise price, then, if certain conditions are satisfied, the Company may require the holders of the
Warrant&nbsp;Cs to exercise up to 50% of the unexercised portions of such warrants. If following the 24&nbsp;month anniversary of the issuance date, the volume weighted average price per share of
the Company's common stock for any 20 consecutive trading days exceeds 300% of the exercise price, then, if certain equity conditions are satisfied, the Company may require the holders of the
Warrant&nbsp;Cs to exercise all or any part of the unexercised portions of such warrants. During 2010 the Company notified the holders of the outstanding Warrant&nbsp;As and Warrant&nbsp;Cs that
the holders were required to exercise 50% of their un-exercised warrants. As a result of this notification by the Company holders of Warrant&nbsp;As exercised </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>63</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> G. WARRANT LIABILITIES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>warrants
to purchase 469,699 shares of common stock and holders of Warrant&nbsp;Cs exercised warrants to purchase 234,849 shares of common stock. Subsequent to December&nbsp;31, 2010 an additional
580,303 Warrant&nbsp;As and 265,152 Warrant&nbsp;Cs were exercised as a result of notification sent out to the remaining holders of the Warrant&nbsp;As and Warrant&nbsp;Cs. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
table below summarizes Black-Scholes option pricing model range of assumptions that were used in valuing the warrants redeemed for both the Warrant&nbsp;As and Warrant&nbsp;Cs. </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
 </DIV>
 <UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Placement Agent Warrants  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;First Albany Capital ("FAC") acted as placement agent in connection with the July&nbsp;19, 2006 private placement. In addition to a
cash transaction fee, FAC or its designees were entitled to receive five-year warrants to purchase 218,182 shares of the Company's common stock at an exercise price of $1.87 per share. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, Placement Agent warrants to purchase 218,182 shares of common stock were outstanding, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Accounting for the Warrants  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon issuance, the Warrant&nbsp;As, Warrant&nbsp;Bs and Warrant&nbsp;Cs, along with the Placement Agent Warrants (together the
"Warrants"), did not meet the requirements for equity classification, because such warrants (a)&nbsp;must be settled in registered shares, (b)&nbsp;are subject to substantial
liquidated damages if the Company is unable to maintain the effectiveness of the resale registration of the shares and (c)&nbsp;there is a cash-out election using a Black-Scholes
valuation under various circumstances. Therefore these Warrants are required to be accounted for as freestanding derivative instruments. Changes in fair value are recognized as either a gain or loss
in the statement of operations under the caption "Change in fair value of notes and warrants." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon
issuance, the Company allocated $2.7&nbsp;million of the initial proceeds to the Warrants and immediately marked them to fair value resulting in a derivative liability of
$4.9&nbsp;million and a charge to other expense of $2.2&nbsp;million. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, the remaining outstanding Warrants have been marked to fair value resulting in a
derivative liability of $5.5&nbsp;million and $5.0&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
credit / (charge) to Change in fair value of notes and warrants, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was ($3.2) million, ($2.6) million and
$0.3&nbsp;million, respectively, related to Warrant&nbsp;As, Bs and Cs and placement agent warrants. The Company also recorded a charge to Change in Fair Value of notes and warrants related to its
Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock warrants of ($3.2) million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>64</FONT></P>

<DIV style="padding:0pt;position:relative;text-align:left;margin-left:10%;">
 <!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
a result of the 2007 Series&nbsp;C preferred stock financing, certain holders of both Warrant&nbsp;As (1,242,426) and Warrant&nbsp;Cs (621,215),
through December&nbsp;31, 2007, exercised their right of redemption, resulting in the Company paying to each redeeming warrant holder the Black-Scholes value of these warrants on the date of
notification of redemption. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, holders of both Warrant&nbsp;As (303,031) and Warrant&nbsp;Cs (151,516) exercised their right of redemption, resulting
in the Company paying to each redeeming warrant holder the Black-Scholes value of these warrants on the date of notification of redemption.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
included in change in fair value of warrants on consolidated statement of operations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>19,799,022
of the Company's issued and outstanding common stock purchase warrants previously treated as equity pursuant to the derivative treatment
exemption were no longer afforded equity treatment. As such, effective January&nbsp;1, 2009 the Company reclassified the fair value of these common stock purchase warrants, which have exercised
price reset features, from equity to liability status as if these warrants were treated as derivative liability since their date of issuance.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;3, 2009, the Company modified certain provisions contained within the common stock purchase warrants issued in connection with the
Series&nbsp;C Preferred Stock financing. See Note&nbsp;C. Significant Accounting Policies and Basis of Consolidation&#151;Warrant&nbsp;Liabilities for a description of the modifications.
As a result of these modifications 19,799,023 of the Company's issued and outstanding common stock purchase warrants, previously treated as a derivative liability on January&nbsp;1, 2009 will now be
treated as equity pursuant to the derivative treatment exemptions afforded the Company. In addition, as a result of this modification, the Company will no longer be required to mark these warrants to
their fair value each quarter. </FONT></DD></DL>
 </DIV>
 <P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>65</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_fu11901_1_66"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg11901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> G. WARRANT LIABILITIES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>
 <DIV style="padding:0pt;position:relative;text-align:left;margin-left:10%;">
<p style="font-family:times;"></FONT></P>
 </DIV>
 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Valuation&#151;Methodology and Significant Assumptions  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The valuation of derivative instruments utilizes certain estimates and judgments that affect the fair value of the instruments. Fair
values for the Company's derivatives are estimated by utilizing valuation models that consider current and expected stock prices, volatility, dividends, forward yield curves and discount rates. Such
amounts and the recognition of such amounts are subject to significant estimates which may change in the future. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
estimating the fair value of the Warrants the following methods and significant input assumptions were applied: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Methods  </I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>An Intrinsic value was utilized to estimate the fair value of Warrant&nbsp;As and Warrant&nbsp;Cs upon their
respective exercise dates during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010. According to options theory, the value of an option equals the sum of its intrinsic value and time value and as it approaches
exercise/expiration date, time value approaches zero. On the date of the exercise/expiration, time value of a warrant becomes zero and the value of the option equals its intrinsic value. Intrinsic
value, for in-the-money options, represents the difference between the strike price and the price of the underlying asset as of expiration/exercise date. Gain/(loss) as of
exercise date is determined based on the difference between the option's intrinsic value and its fair value as of last measurement/reporting date, with any decrease (increase) in value representing a
gain (loss).  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>A binomial lattice model was utilized to estimate the fair value of Warrant&nbsp;As and Warrant&nbsp;Cs on the dates
in the corresponding table below, as well as the fair value of the Placement Agent Warrants on the dates in the corresponding table below. The binomial model considers the key features of the
Warrants, and is subject to the significant assumptions discussed below. First, a discrete simulation of the Company's stock price was conducted at each node and throughout the expected life of the
instrument. Second, an analysis of the higher of a holding position (</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>i.e</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>., fair value of a future node value discounted using an applicable discount
rate) or exercise position was conducted relative to each node, which considers the non-exercise period, until a </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>66</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=66,EFW="2202706",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=590356,FOLIO='66',FILE='DISK106:[11ZAE1.11ZAE11901]FU11901A.;8',USER='JJORGE',CD='14-MAR-2011;23:13' -->
<A NAME="page_fu11901_1_67"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg11901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> G. WARRANT LIABILITIES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>final
fair value of the instrument is concluded at the node representing the valuation date. This model requires the following key inputs with respect to the Company and/or instrument: </FONT></P>

</UL>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">

 <!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE  COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" >


<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>Warrant&nbsp;Cs
were issued on July&nbsp;17, 2007 upon the exercise of the Warrant&nbsp;Bs. </FONT></DD></DL>
 </DIV>
 <DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>A
Black-Scholes option pricing model was utilized to estimate the fair value of Placement Agent Warrants on the dates in the corresponding table shown
below. A change in method from the binomial to Black-Scholes was warranted because the warrants' non-exercise period ended prior to the valuation date and all required inputs were fixed.
This model requires the following key inputs with respect to the Company and/or instrument: </FONT></DD></DL>
 <DIV style="padding:0pt;position:relative;width:60%;margin-left:20%;">
<p style="font-family:times;"><font size=1></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>

 </DIV>
 <UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Significant Assumptions:  </I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Stock volatility was estimated by annualizing the daily volatility of the Company's stock price during the historical
period preceding the respective valuation dates and measured over a period </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>67</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=67,EFW="2202706",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=573820,FOLIO='67',FILE='DISK106:[11ZAE1.11ZAE11901]FU11901A.;8',USER='JJORGE',CD='14-MAR-2011;23:13' -->
<A NAME="page_fu11901_1_68"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
HREF="#bg11901a_main_toc">Table of Contents</A></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> G. WARRANT LIABILITIES (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>corresponding
to the remaining life of the instruments. Historic stock prices were used to estimate volatility as the Company did not have traded options as of the valuation dates; </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The volume weighted average price for the 20 trading days preceding a payment date was reasonably approximated by the
average of the simulated stock price at each respective node of the binomial model;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Based on the Company's historical operations and management expectations for the near future, the Company's stock was
assumed to be a non-dividend-paying stock;  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The quoted market price of the Company's stock was utilized in the valuations because the derivative guidance requires the
use of quoted market prices without considerations of blockage discounts. The quoted market price of the Company's stock as of measurement dates and expected future stock prices were assumed to
reflect the effect of dilution upon conversion of the instruments to shares of common stock. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> H. DEBT INSTRUMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On February&nbsp;26, 2008, the Company entered into a Loan and Security Agreement (the "Loan Agreement") with Silicon Valley Bank (the "Bank"). Under the terms of the Loan Agreement,
the Bank agreed to provide the Company with a credit line up to $10.0&nbsp;million. The Company's obligations under the Loan Agreement are secured by substantially all of the assets of the Company
and advances under the Loan Agreement are limited to 80% of eligible receivables and the lesser of 25% of the value of the Company's eligible inventory, as defined, or $1.0&nbsp;million. Interest on
outstanding borrowings accrued at a rate per annum equal to the Prime Rate plus one percent (1.0%) per annum, as defined, or the LIBOR Rate plus three and three quarter percent (3.75%) per annum. The
Loan Agreement contained certain financial covenants relating to tangible net worth, as defined, which the Company must satisfy in order to borrow under the agreement. In addition, the Company agreed
to pay to the Bank a collateral monitoring fee of $750 per month and agreed to the following additional terms: (i)&nbsp;$50,000 commitment fee, $25,000 to be paid at signing of the Loan Agreement
and $25,000 to be paid on the one year anniversary of the Loan Agreement; (ii)&nbsp;an unused line fee in the amount of 0.5% per annum of the average unused portion of the revolving line; and
(iii)&nbsp;an early termination fee of 0.5% of the total credit line if the Company terminated the Loan Agreement prior to 12&nbsp;months from the Loan Agreement's effective date. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2010, the Company entered into several amendments to Loan Agreement. At December&nbsp;31, 2010 the terms of the Loan Agreement are as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(i)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Loan Agreement expires on October&nbsp;18, 2011,
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(ii)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
credit line was increased to $15,000,000,
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(iii)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Interest
on outstanding formula-based borrowings accrues at a rate per annum equal to the Prime Rate plus one half percent (.50%) per annum,
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(iv)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the
Company's tangible net worth covenant, as defined, was eliminated
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(v)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the
Company's liquidity covenant, as defined, was set at approximately $5.0&nbsp;million until March&nbsp;31, 2011 and thereafter at approximately
$6.5&nbsp;million and </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>68</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008 </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> H. DEBT INSTRUMENTS (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(vi)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>a
covenant relating to adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization ("Adjusted EBITDA"), was added.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(vii)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's obligation under the Loan Agreement continues to be secured by substantially all of the assets of the Company. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2010 and December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had $15.0&nbsp;million and $3.0&nbsp;million outstanding under the Loan Agreement and the Bank's prime rate was
4%. The rate used was the Bank's prime rate of 4.0% plus 0.50% (or 4.5% at December&nbsp;31, 2010) and 4.0% plus 1% (or 5% at December&nbsp;31, 2009). Subsequent to December&nbsp;31, 2010 the
Company repaid $15.0&nbsp;million outstanding on the line of credit. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company was in compliance with the liquidity and Adjusted EBITDA covenant requirements. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company had $0 available under the line of credit. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Notes Payable  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;16, 2010, the Company entered into a Venture Loan and Security Agreement with Compass Horizon Funding Company&nbsp;LLC
(the "Lender") pursuant to which the Lender has loaned the Company $12,000,000 (the "Subordinated Loan"). After the Lender's closing fees and expenses, the net proceeds to the Company were
$11,826,500. Interest on the Subordinated Loan will accrue at a rate per annum equal to 12.58%. The Subordinated Loan is subordinated to up to $15,000,000 of senior indebtedness, provided that from
and after August&nbsp;31, 2010, the senior indebtedness cannot exceed an amount equal to 80% of the Company's accounts receivable plus 40% of its inventory. The Subordinated Loan is to be repaid
over 42&nbsp;months following the closing. From June&nbsp;15, 2010 through April&nbsp;30, 2011, the Company is only required to pay interest on the Subordinated Loan and thereafter the
Subordinated Loan will be repaid in 33 substantially equal monthly installments of interest and principal. The Subordinated Loan may be prepaid by the Company by paying all accrued interest through
the date of payment, the then outstanding principal balance and a prepayment premium equal to a declining percentage of the principal amount outstanding at the time of prepayment (initially 4% during
the first twelve months of the subordinated Loan, decreasing to 3% for the succeeding twelve months and 2% thereafter). In connection with the Subordinated Loan, the Company has issued to the Lender
five year warrants to acquire up to an aggregate of 591,716 shares of the Company's common stock at an exercise price of $2.43 per share (which was the 20-day trailing volume weighted
average price of the Company's common stock). The relative fair value of the warrants was $0.9&nbsp;million and will be recorded as interest expense over the term of the loan. The Company estimated
the fair value of the warrants using the Black-Scholes option pricing model using the following assumptions: </FONT></P>
 <DIV style="padding:0pt;position:relative;width:60%;margin-left:20%;">
<p style="font-family:times;"><font size=1></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>

 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> I. REDEEMABLE CONVERTIBLE SERIES B AND SERIES C PREFERRED STOCK  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Series&nbsp;B Convertible Preferred Stock  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company completed a $7.7&nbsp;million equity transaction involving the issuance of 1,535 shares of
its Series&nbsp;B Convertible Preferred Stock, $0.01 par value per share (the "Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock"), and warrants to purchase up to 1,228,000 shares of the
Company's common stock, to accredited investors (the "October 2003 Financing Transaction"). In connection with the October 2003 Financing Transaction, the Company issued shares of Series&nbsp;B
Preferred Stock for $5,000 per share. The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock was convertible into a number of shares of common stock equal to $5,000 divided by the conversion price of the Series&nbsp;B
Preferred Stock, which was initially $2.50. As of December&nbsp;31, 2009, and 2008 the conversion price for the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock was $1.49 (as a result of adjustments to the
conversion price following issuance in accordance with the terms of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock) and$1.55, respectively. During 2009, 215 shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were
converted by their holders resulting in the Company issuing 719,528 shares of common stock. During 2010, the remaining 75 shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were converted by their holders
resulting in the company issuing 251,677 shares of common stock. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, 0 and 75 shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were outstanding, respectively. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2009, the liquidation preference of the remaining 75 shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock was $375,000, and these were convertible into 251,677 shares of common stock. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
a result of the issuance of shares of approximately 17.9&nbsp;million shares of common stock during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company adjusted the conversion
price on the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock to $1.49 from $1.55 at December&nbsp;31, 2008 and recorded a charge of $55,369. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Dividends on Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock initially bore a cumulative dividend at a rate of 6% per annum; pursuant to its terms,
this was increased to a rate of rate of 8% per annum on October&nbsp;1, 2005. Dividends on the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were payable semi-annually and, except in certain limited
circumstances, were entitled to be paid by the Company, at its option, either through the issuance of shares of common stock or in cash. The Company elected to pay the dividend in shares of common
stock, and issued a number of shares of common stock equal to the quotient of the dividend payment divided by the greater of 80% of the average closing bid and ask price of the common stock on the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>70</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

 <P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
part of the October 2003 Financing Transaction, the Company also issued warrants to purchase up to 1,228,000 shares of its common stock. These warrants were exercisable for a
five-year term and had an initial exercise price of $3.32 per share. These warrants expired unexercised in 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Liquidation Preference on Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the event of a liquidation of the Company, the holders of shares of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock would have been entitled to
receive a liquidation payment prior to the payment of any amount with respect to the shares of the common stock. The amount of this preferential liquidation payment would have been $5,000 per share of
Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock, plus the amount of any accrued but unpaid dividends on those shares. This entitlement to a liquidation preference was eliminated upon the holders' conversion of the
Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock into common shares in October 2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Mandatory Conversion of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If certain conditions described below are met, each share of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock will be automatically converted into a
number of shares of common stock equal to $5,000 divided by the conversion price of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock, which was initially $2.50, but which has since been adjusted in accordance with
the terms of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock to $1.49 and $1.55 (as of December&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008, respectively). Mandatory conversion may only occur if the average of the closing bid and
ask price of the common stock on the Nasdaq Stock Market exceeds $5.00 (as adjusted for stock splits, stock dividends, combinations and similar transactions) for 20 consecutive trading days and either
the registration statement governing the underlying shares of common stock is effective or the shares of common stock issuable upon conversion of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock can be sold
without restriction pursuant to Rule&nbsp;144 of the Securities Act of 1933. The mandatory conversion date will be extended for so long as the following events have occurred and are
continuing: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the effectiveness of the registration statement covering the resale of the shares of common stock issuable upon the
conversion of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock lapses for 20 consecutive trading days (other than as a result of factors solely in control of the holders of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock) and
the shares of common stock into which the shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock are convertible cannot be sold without restriction pursuant to Rule&nbsp;144; </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>71</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><BR>
SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> DECEMBER 31, 2010, 2009 AND 2008  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> I. REDEEMABLE CONVERTIBLE SERIES B AND SERIES C PREFERRED STOCK (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the common stock is suspended from listing without subsequent listing on any one of, or is not listed on at least one of,
the Nasdaq Global Market, the Nasdaq Capital Market, the OTC Bulletin Board, the New York Stock Exchange,&nbsp;Inc. or the American Stock Exchange,&nbsp;Inc. for five consecutive trading days; </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the Company provides notice to the holders of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock that it will not or cannot comply with a
proper conversion notice; or  </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the Company fails to comply with a proper conversion notice within 10 business days of receipt of that notice. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If,
however, on the mandatory conversion date, a holder is prohibited from converting all of its shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock as a result of the restrictions described below
under "Conversion Restrictions," such shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock will not be converted, will remain outstanding and will not accrue any dividends. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Conversion Restrictions  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unless the Company seeks and obtains stockholder approval, the number of shares of common stock the Company may issue upon the
conversion of the shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock (when aggregated with the number of shares of common stock issued as dividends on the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and upon exercise of
the warrants issued to the placement agent and its affiliates for the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock financing) is limited to 4,947,352 shares (representing 19.999% of the Company's total outstanding
common stock as of October&nbsp;31, 2003 immediately prior to the issuance of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock). In addition, no holder may convert shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock if
conversion of those shares would result in the holder owning more than 4.99% of the common stock then outstanding or would result in the holder beneficially owning more than 9.999% of the common stock
then outstanding, unless the holder waives this limitation at least 61&nbsp;days prior to the proposed conversion. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Failure to Convert  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If for any reason upon an optional or mandatory conversion the Company cannot issue shares of common stock which have been registered
for resale pursuant to an effective registration statement, then the Company will be obligated to issue as many shares of common stock as its is able to issue. If the Company does not have enough
shares of common stock to cover the conversion of all outstanding shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock, then with respect to the unconverted shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock (other than
unconverted Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock resulting from the restrictions described above under "Conversion Restrictions"), the holder will have the right to (i)&nbsp;void its conversion notice,
(ii)&nbsp;require the Company to redeem the unconverted shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock at a price per share equal to $6,250 plus liquidated damages and any accrued but unpaid dividends or
(iii)&nbsp;require the Company to issue shares of common stock that have not been registered pursuant to the Securities Act. If the holder elects redemption, the Company may pay the redemption price
either in cash or in shares of common stock based on the quotient of the redemption price divided by the greater of 80% of the average of the closing bid and ask price of the common stock on the
Nasdaq Stock Market for the 15 trading days ending on the 11th&nbsp;trading day prior to the redemption date and the conversion price, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>72</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

was initially $2.50, but which has since been adjusted in accordance with the terms of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock to $1.49, $1.55 and $1.55 (as of December&nbsp;31, 2009, 2008, and
2007 respectively). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Accounting for the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and Adjustments to the Conversion Price  </I></FONT></P>

of the redeemable convertible Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and the warrants issued to the investors, and then to any beneficial conversion rights contained in the convertible redeemable preferred
securities as follows: </FONT></P>
